children.name: to cheat in an examination or game
cheat
children.definition: /tʃiːt/  to use dishonest methods in order to pass an examination or win a game:
examples: gian lận
▪ Studies indicate about 20 to 30 percent of college students cheat.cheat at
▪ Jenny always cheats at cards.
cheating[uncountable noun] when someone cheats in an examination or game::
gian giận
▪ Their teacher suspected them of cheating when they both missed the same question on the test.

children.name: copy
children.definition: /ˈkɒpiǁˈkɑː-/  to cheat in an examination, schoolwork etc by copying someone’s work:
examples: sao chép
▪ If I see anyone copying I’ll send you straight to the principal’s office.
copy off
sao chép hết
▪ The only way I made it through high school was by copying off my best friend.
copy something from something
sao chép cái gì từ cái gì
▪ She was expelled for handing in an essay that she had copied directly from a newspaper article.

children.name: test
children.definition: a set ofspokenorwrittenquestions or practical activities, which are intended to find out how much sb knows about a subject or skill: bài kiểm tra
examples: I have a chemistry test tomorrow.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'make a test'. Saytake a testordo a test.

children.name: take a test
children.definition: alsodo/sit a testBritish English
examples: All candidates have to take a test.

children.name: pass a test
children.definition: succeed in it
examples: She passed her driving test first time.

children.name: fail a test
children.definition: alsoflunk a testAmerican English informal
examples: He failed the test and had to take it again.

children.name: do well/badly in a test
examples: British English,do well/badly on a testAmerican English I didn’t do very well in the first part of the test.

children.name: give sb a test
examples: The students were given a reading test.

children.name: grade a test
children.definition: alsomark a testBritish English
examples: I spent the day marking tests.

children.name: a biology/history etc test
examples: On Monday we had a French test.

children.name: a spelling/reading/listening test
examples: I didn’t do very well in the listening test.

children.name: a driving/ driver’s test
examples: A driving test can be a nerve-racking experience.

children.name: a written test
examples: Selection was based on written tests in English and mathematics.

children.name: a multiple choice test
children.definition: in which each question has a list of answers to choose from
examples: There is some debate about whether multiple-choice tests are a good way of assessing student’s knowledge.

children.name: an aptitude test
children.definition: a test that measures your natural abilities

children.name: an oral test
examples: The oral test will consist of a conversation of about 10 minutes in German.

children.name: a test paper
examples: The teacher began handing out the test papers.

children.name: a test result/score
examples: The test results are out on Friday.

children.name: a test question
examples: Some of the test questions were really difficult.

children.name: test on
examples: We have a test on irregular verbs tomorrow.
Did you get a good mark in the test ?

children.name: exam
children.definition: / examinationformal animportanttest that you do at theend of acourseof study or at the end of the school year: bài thi
examples: Students are not allowed to talk during the examination.
He’s upstairs, revising for an exam.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'make an exam'. Saytake an examordo an exam.

children.name: a chemistry/
examples: French etc examI knew I wouldn’t pass the German exam.

children.name: a written exam
examples: There is a written exam at the end of the course.

children.name: an oral exam[oralUK]
children.definition: in which you answer questions by speaking
examples: I have my French oral exams next week.

children.name: a mock examUK/mocksUK
children.definition: one that you do to practise for the real exams
examples: bài thi thử

children.name: a practical exam[practicalUK]
children.definition: in which you have to make or do things
examples: There’s a practical exam as well as a written one.

children.name: a final exam
children.definition: at the end of a course
examples: The students take their final exams in June.

children.name: the end of year/term exam
examples: BrE: I knew I had to do well in the end of year exams.

children.name: high school exams
examples: Greg got good grades in all of his high school exams.

children.name: an entrance exam
children.definition: in order to enter a school or university
examples: Jane passed the entrance exam but decided not to go.

children.name: a professional exam
children.definition: to qualify in a profession, for example to be an accountant
examples: Once you’ve passed your professional exams, you can start to build up your experience.

children.name: the bar exam
children.definition: in order to become a lawyer
examples: He is studying for the bar exam.

children.name: board examsAmerican English
children.definition: in order to become a nurse or doctor
examples: He failed his board exams in psychiatry.

children.name: exam results
examples: The school achieves consistently good exam results.

children.name: an exam paper
examples: I’ve still got dozens of exam papers to mark.

children.name: an exam question
examples: Read the exam questions carefully before writing your answers.

children.name: exam revision
examples: BrE: I have to do my exam revision this weekend.

children.name: exam practice
examples: Schools say they have to spend too much time doing exam practice.

children.name: an exam essay/script
children.definition: that someone has written during an exam
examples: I’ve brought in some old exam scripts for us to look at.

children.name: exam technique
children.definition: good ways to succeed in exams
examples: Mr Frasier gave us some useful tips on exam technique.

children.name: exam marks
examples: Pupils were divided into classes with a similar range of ability, based on their previous exam marks.

children.name: take/do an exam
children.definition: alsosit an examBritish English
examples: We have to take exams at the end of each year.

children.name: pass an exam
children.definition: succeed in it
examples: Did you pass your final exam?

children.name: fail an exam
examples: If you fail the exam, you can retake it.

children.name: do well/badly in an exam
examples: British English,do well/badly on an examAmEː Maria always did well in her exams at school.

children.name: study for an exam
children.definition: alsorevise for an examBritish English
examples: She has to study for her exams.

children.name: sail though an exam
children.definition: pass it easily
examples: Don’t worry - I'm sure you’ll sail through all your exams.

children.name: scrape through an exam
children.definition: only just pass it
examples: He managed to scrape through the exam and stay on the course.

children.name: flunk an examAmerican English informal
children.definition: fail it
examples: I flunked all my first year exams.

children.name: cheat in an exam
examples: British English,cheat on an examAmE: She was caught cheating in the exam.

children.name: retake an exam
children.definition: alsoresit an examBritish English
examples: (= take it again because you did not do well the first time )If you don’t do well, you’ll have to resit the exam in January.

children.name: in an examUK /on an examUS trong bài thi
examples: How did you do in your exams?
He did well in the mock exams.

children.name: quiz
children.definition: US aquicktest that a teacher gives to a class, usually to check that students are learning the things they should be learning: bài kiểm tra nhanh
examples: We have a history quiz every Monday.

children.name: pop quiza quiz that is not expected by the students kiểm tra bất ngờ
examples: He likes giving pop quizzes, to see if the kids are remembering anything.

children.name: finals
children.definition: UK the last exams that you take at the end of a UK university course: đợt thi cuối cùng
examples: During my finals I was revising till 3 o'clock in the morning most days.

children.name: final
children.definition: US an important test that you take at the end of a particular class in high school or college : bài kiểm tra cuối kì
examples: The English final was pretty hard.
This class will require two papers, a midterm, and a final.

children.name: midterm
children.definition: US an important test that you take in the middle of a term, covering what you have learned in a particular class in high school or college: bài kiểm tra giữa kì
examples: He did badly in the midterm.

children.name: to do a test or exam
take
children.definition: làm
examples: Anna will be taking her music exam in the summer.
Most young people take the SAT exams in their last year of high school.
I took my driving test when I was 18.

children.name: have
children.definition: / have got if you have an examtomorrow, next week etc,you are going to do it then:có
examples: We have a quiz every week on what we’ve been reading.
I have a written exam in the morning and an interview in the afternoon.
Lucy’s got her driving test next week.

children.name: do
children.definition: UK do is more informal that take, and is used especially in conversation: làm
examples: I’d better go home -- I’ve got to do an exam in the morning.
The kids are doing a test this morning.

children.name: sit
children.definition: UK to do a written school or college exam: làm
examples: I sat my final exams last year.
After I've sat my exams, I'm going on holiday.

children.name: pass
children.definition: /  to reach a high enough standard to succeed in an examination or test:đậu

children.name: ‘I’m taking my driving test today.’ ‘Do you think you’ll pass?’
examples: New recruits have to pass a physical fitness test.

children.name: pass with flying coloursBritish /colorsAmerican pass a test or examination with very high marks đậu với số điểm cao
examples: She was so nervous about her examination results, but in fact she passed with flying colours.

children.name: scrape through
children.definition: especially UK,informalto only just pass an examination, by getting only a few marks more than arenecessary: vượt qua
examples: Daniel scraped through the entrance exam.
I scraped through my exams with marks just good enough to keep my place in the school of pharmacy.

children.name: qualify
children.definition: especially UK to pass all the examinations that you need in order to becomeadoctor, lawyer, engineer etc: đủ trình độ, đạt trình độ
examples: After qualifying, she joined the NatWest Bank as a corporate advisor.

children.name: qualify as
examples: She wanted to improve her English so she could qualify as a translator.

children.name: get through
children.definition: to pass a difficult test or examination: vượt qua
examples: The entrance exam is very difficult and only a small minority of candidates get through.

children.name: get through sth
examples: She got through her exams without too much trouble.

children.name: sail through
children.definition: sail/ breeze through informal to pass a test or examination very easily:
examples: ‘How’d his exams go?’ "He breezed through - no trouble at all.

children.name: sail/breeze through sth
examples: She sailed through her driving test the first time.

children.name: be given a pass
children.definition: đậu
examples: My teacher told me she passed me only because she knew I’d had a really hard year.
I didn’t think the candidate deserved to be given a pass but the other examiners disagreed.

children.name: to give students a test or exam
give sb a test
children.definition: to make sb do a test: đưa ra bài thi
examples: Schools are required to give students national standardized tests.

children.name: give sb a test on
examples: The French teacher gave us a test on irregular verbs, and I got 100%.

children.name: test
children.definition: to ask sbwrittenorspokenquestions to find out what they know about a subject:kiểm tra
examples: New students are tested in math and reading, and placed in the appropriate class.

children.name: test sb on sth
examples: Tomorrow you’ll be tested on the main events of the Civil War.

children.name: set sb an exam
children.definition: UK to choose the questions that are in a test or exam: ra đề
examples: Next lesson I’m setting you all a test to see how much you’ve learned.
Whoever set the exam didn’t seem to know the material very well.

children.name: set sb a test
children.definition: UK to choose the questions that are in a test or exam: ra đề
examples: Next lesson I’m setting you all a test to see how much you’ve learned.
Whoever set the exam didn’t seem to know the material very well.

children.name: examine
children.definition: formalto ask sb questions in an exam in order to find out what they know about a particular subject:kiểm tra
examples: To save time, students will be examined in groups of three.

children.name: examine sb on sth
examples: Students will be examined on all aspects of Russian literature and history.
We were examinedonEuropean history.
UKYou'll be examinedinthree main areas; speaking, listening and reading comprehension.

children.name: fail
children.definition: to not succeed in an examination or test:trượt
examples: Jonathan failed his law exams at the end of the year.
If I fail my driving test again, I’m going to give up.

children.name: ‘How did you do in accountancy?’ ‘I failed’
examples: Many of the boys in the program had been failing at school.
I passed in history but failedinchemistry.

children.name: fail by 2 marks/ 5% etc
examples: We expected her to pass easily, but she failed by 15 marks.

children.name: flunk
children.definition: especially US,informalto fail an examination or test:trượt
examples: He thought he was going to flunk chemistry, but he got a D.
I flunked, and had to do the test again.
He was cutting school and flunking classes.
She flunked the state bar exam four times before she finally passed.

children.name: flunk outfail all your classes, so that you have to leave school bị đuổi học
examples: Brant flunked out of college his first year.
You either pass and get your degree or flunk out.

children.name: flunk out of college/school etc
examples: It was extremely humiliating to flunk out of law school like that.

children.name: bomb
children.definition: US informal to fail very badly:rớt thê thảm
examples: I bombed the English test yesterday.
I bombed on the quiz he gave us.

children.name: ‘How’d it go?’ ‘I bombed on the written section, but I think I did okay on the multiple choice part.’
to do a test or exam again
retake
children.definition: to do a test or exam again because you have previously failed it: làm cái gì lại lần nữa
examples: She wants to retake her French A-level exam.
Ralph retook his driver’s test in June.

children.name: resit
children.definition: UK to do a written school or college exam again because you have previously failed it: thi lại
examples: It only makes sense to resit an exam if you strongly believe you will do better.

children.name: take again
children.definition: take sth again to do a test or exam again because you have previously failed it: làm cái gì lại lần nữa
examples: If you fail the test, you can always take it again

children.name: examiner
children.definition: UK sb who judges exams or tests: người chấm thi
examples: The examiner told him to relax and then asked him to turn on the engine.
Students who, in the opinion of the examiners, do not reach the required standard must take the exam again.

children.name: candidate
children.definition: UK sb who does an exam: thí sinh
examples: Candidates should be at their desks 5 minutes before the start of the examination.
Candidates must write their names on the top page of the exam paper.

children.name: a system of using exams and tests
assessment
children.definition: especially UK a method used to find out how good a student is at a particular subject, for example by giving them written work, tests, or exams: cáchđánh giá (kết quả học tập)
examples: Assessment is by means of a written exam at the end of the course.

children.name: continuous assessmentassessment throughout a student’s course of study, instead of only at the end đánh giá liên tục
examples: Most schools nowadays prefer to use continuous assessment, because it gives a fairer picture of how the student has done during the whole year.

children.name: testing
children.definition: the system of using exams and tests to find out how good sb is at a particular subject:kiểm tra, đánh giá
examples: The government plans to introduce compulsory testing in junior schools from the age of 7.
I believe that some sort of testing is always necessary in order to motivate students.

children.name: to make sb pass a test
pass
children.definition: cho đậu
examples: My teacher told me she passed me only because she knew I’d had a really hard year.

children.name: qualify
children.definition: if sth qualifies you to do sth, you have the necessary skills, knowledge, ability etc to do it

children.name: qualify sb for sth
examples: Fluency in three languages qualifies her for work in the European Parliament.

children.name: qualify sb to do sth
examples: The certificate qualifies you to work as a dental assistant.
This course qualifies youtoteach in any secondary school.

children.name: get through
children.definition: get sb through sth to pass a difficult test or examination: vượt qua
examples: Reading that book at the last minute was the only thing that got me through the history exam.

children.name: to make sb fail a test
fail
children.definition: to judge that someone has been unsuccessful in a test or examination : đánh trượt
examples: The examiners failed him because he hadn't answered enough questions.

children.name: exercise
children.definition: a set of questions in a book that test a student’s knowledge or skill : bài tập
examples: Do Exercises 3 and 4 on page 51 for homework.
The exercises in Chapter 3 are helpful for students learning the future tense.

children.name: a book of guitar exercises to improve finger flexibility
examples: The book has exercises at the end of every chapter.

children.name: paper
children.definition: UK a set of printed questions used as an examination in a particular subject, or the answers people write : đề thi/ bài làm
examples: The geography paper is not till next week.
The history paper was really difficult.
The papers are marked by the other teachers.
Candidates must answer two questions from each paper.
